ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Lots of information about ethical ethnography, how to do archival work and just what latinx studies looks like in practice!
An understanding of ethnography, its many applications and characteristic for ethnic studies
I learned about various ethnographic methods, as well as the history of Latinx ethnography.
I learned how to craft interview questions that will yield substantive answers. I also learned how affect can reveal peoples beliefs about race, ethnicity, etc.
Methods and experience with oral histories, archival work.

This course really helped hone in my analytical skills and my writing skills. I was about to learn more about the method of ethnography which I only had previous knowledge about before. Professor Ramos-Zayas provides great feedback that makes this class incredibly worthwhile.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths! I feel like the class was structured with the perfect balance of structure, creativity and varied assignments.
There are many strengths from the projects to the instruction, I just wish the goal of the course or the goal that the course is hoping to teach us clarified

I highly recommend this class! It is a great methods class, particularly for anyone who wants to learn more about ethnography. I didn't think the workload was too overwhelming. Professor Ramos Zayas is incredibly insightful, and her expertise in the field really shines through in class. She put a lot of thought into the structure of the class, and did a fantastic job curating a syllabus for this semester.  The assignments were also markedly different from other ER&M classes I have taken, and were very much hands-on.

Strengths: professor is knowledgeable, passionate, and great at cultivating a comfortable and productive discussion setting
Weaknesses: more clarity around whether it is in fact a graduate course, like just putting a statement on the syllabus maybe saying that (rather than saying it implicitly by saying graduate students will also be in the class)

The course was taught perfectly. We read a wide range of readings, which allowed us to learn about Latinx ethnography through a variety of lens. The work, specially the oral histories and the box inventories, we did felt incredibly meaningful and impactful to the documentation of Latinx people at Yale. The reading responses were doable and the final paper was incredibly fun to write as we were given free will to write about whatever we wanted. Great class!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES 1000% I feel like it completely changed my perspective on what ethnography and Latinx studies can look like

I would absolutely recommend this class to other Yale students! I will caution that I might not recommend it to first years and sophomores, as some of the theoretical insights from the class might not be as useful.
Yes! You will learn useful techniques for conducting research, especially with Latinx subjects. The work is also very meaningful and personally rewarding.
Yes! This was a great class for a non-ER&M major like myself.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student especially if you are a Latinx student at Yale who would like to learn more about the histories and legacies of people who were here before. Even if not, ethnography is a useful tool that helps you understand the world and its racialized populations.

Yes! This is such an amazing class. All the readings are so interesting and the themes and conclusions are applicable to real life situations and events. Professor Ramos-Zayas is an incredible professor who really knows what they are doing and how to best teach and help her students. 10/10 class!
